comments:
RC2 (on RC1 this problem did not occur)

I use self-written import plugin, allowing importing several projects at once.
Functionality is quite simple - user gets list of available projects in a 
directory, select some and then the projects are created in the workspace and 
opened afterwards.
Now after opening every Java PDE project (PDEs, which have only libs, no 
sources, opening without errors) I have the following exception:

Here's one more scenario that causes this:

- connect to CVS repository dev.eclipse.org
- retrieve projects org.eclipse.swt through org.eclipse.swt.win32, excluding 
org.eclipse.swt.gtk1x
- in the org.eclipse.swt project select the .classpath_win32 file, right-click -
> Copy
- select the org.eclipse.swt project, right-click -> Paste
- in the subsequent name conflict dialog enter ".classpath" (no quotes), OK
- this will compile swt, but near the end will write the exception and show 
an "Internal error..." dialog
*** Bug 34323 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 34334 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The manifest builder was requesting a delta for a non-existent project.  Our API
explicitly allows this, but I guess nobody had ever tried it before.  This is
fairly severe - if you have a PDE project that depends on a plugin that does not
exist in the workspace, you will get this error.

I will attach a patch with a suggested fix.
We are happy to contribute to testing the Core this way :-).
I am just happy I'm not the only one seeing it. ;-}

Fix approved by KevinM and DJ.  Fix reviewed by JohnA and DJ.


Tests added in MultiProjectBuildTest.  Released.

Sorry to ask, but Eclipse doesn't make it convenient to track the chain of
getDelta calls back to the internal caller.

1) I am assuming the null return simply makes the caller ignore the project and
doesn't trip yet another assertion?

2) The only way I can see this arose in my case is if I checked out a project
that had a dependency on a project that is not in the workspace at all and was
not actually required. Unfortunately, there seems to be no UI that will allow me
to discover what that dependency is, as only projects that do exist in the
workspace appear in the UI. Shouldn't there be? Or am I mistaken about how this
happened?

1) That is correct.  A null delta means we don't have any information on that 
project.  An empty delta means we know about the project, and we know nothing 
has changed.  The spec for the getDelta() method is pretty clear that null is a 
valid return value.  We double-checked that the PDE manifest builder handles 
this correctly.




2) This bug arose when you had a PDE project in your workspace, and a project it 
depended on was not available in the workspace.  A plugin's depedencies can be 
viewed in the plugin.xml file (the "requires" element).  A special case is that 
org.eclipse.core.runtime plugin is an implicit dependency.  That is, even if you 
don't specify it in your plugin.xml, it will be internally recognized as a 
required plugin.




I encourage you to retry your scenario with today's integration build when it 
becomes available.  Let us know if you still have a problem.
